results.title: Vida Longa = Long Life
results.creator_credit: Vicki Banwell, Bertie Films and Channel 4
results.brief_description: Visually rich and culturally loaded, ‘Vida Longa’ is an intimate journey, a simple game, between one of the oldest and youngest Capoeira Masters in history.
results.description: Visually rich and culturally loaded, ‘Vida Longa’ is an intimate journey, a simple game, between one of the oldest and youngest Capoeira Masters in history.

results.title: The Voorman Problem
results.creator_credit: Mark Gill, Baldwin Li, Alastair Connolly and Honlodge
results.brief_description: Doctor Williams, a psychiatrist, is called to a prison to examine Voorman – an inmate with a peculiar affliction – he believes he is a god. The problem is, though, that he’s managed to convince the rest of the prison population that he is indeed telling the truth.

results.title: Tumult
results.creator_credit: Johnny Barrington, Rhianna Andrews, Channel 4 Television, Young Films (UK) and Creative Scotland
results.brief_description: A tribe of Norse warriors traipse across a barren land after battle. Bloodied and wounded, their chief is near death. He is about to hand over power to his son when a completely different kind of army descend upon them.

results.title: Two and Two
results.creator_credit: Babak Anvari, Kit Fraser and Flick Art
results.brief_description: In a school governed by a strict regime, the pupils are informed that what they had always been taught as fact is no longer true. But when the incredulous students speak out, they are forced to question how far they will go to stand up for their beliefs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Babak Anvari, Kit Fraser and Flick Art

results.title: Until My Heart's, Like, Finished
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Phil Shepherd, Martin Hodgson, Somerset Film and First Light
results.brief_description: On the day of your 16th birthday, your mum kicks you out of home for good. You live in a car. You sofa surf. You sleep rough. Life for these young people has been tough with many challenges. Here they tell their stories in their own words, reveal they have learnt about how to survive and make plans for putting their lives back together.

results.title: Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage interview
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, Warwick talks about his early days in Alice Springs and getting his start in radio before moving on to films. Warwick also discusses the reoccurring theme of the matriarch in his works and the freedom and joy he finds in installation art.

‘Mother Courage’ is a film and sculptural installation by the internationally acclaimed artist and filmmaker Warwick Thornton. Co-commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA (13) as part of the ACMI Commissions Series, ‘Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage’ was a free exhibition in Gallery Two at ACMI 2013. As one of the most exciting filmmakers working in Australia today, Warwick Thornton is best known for ‘Samson & Delilah’, winner of the 2009 Camera d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. His work, ‘Mother Courage’ (2012), is a dynamic, multi-screen art installation that features a dilapidated campervan as its centrepiece. Audiences will peer into the van’s grimy windows and through its rear doors, to view the provocative and poignant video contained within.

results.title: Wish
results.creator_credit: Araine Moir, Emily Abernethy and Elizabeth Kuiper
results.brief_description:
A young girl is transported into a fantasy world where her birthday wishes manifest into something beyond her control. This film questions the importance we place on superficial and materialistic desires.

Under the category ‘Best Overall Secondary School Entry’, Year 12, Presbyterian Ladies’ College, Peppermint Grove, WA, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: You don't belong here [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
By staying true to your own ideals you will find a group of unique individuals where everyone belongs. A man is shipwrecked on a distant island. He must search the island for a tribe to live in by avoiding obstacles and collecting gems along the way. These tribes will take you in but on the condition you behave like them. You decline their offer saying you have a right to be yourself. You are then banished and must avoid members of these tribes as you continue your search. They attempt to catch you as you dont belong. Finally you come across a tribe that accepts you for who you are. They are all individuals and make you feel like you belong.

Under the category ‘Primary Videogames’, Liam Blake, Hope Valley, SA, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Unshaded
results.brief_description:
‘Unshaded’ is a stop-motion animation made from plasticine. It explores the notion that no matter who you are, there is always a place of belonging for you. The animation is initially shot in a black and white world, reflecting the character’s thoughts of loneliness and insecurity. The character is confronted by unfamiliar creatures who seek to gain their colour back by signalling to him to tap them on the head. He does this and in return his world is restored to colour. The character realises that together they can bring happiness to each other and ultimately belong even though they may have evident differences.

Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Hayley Warnock, Benalla, Victoria, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Sunday's dog
results.creator_credit: Fionnuala Keith, Maddie Jamieson Goddard and Pepper Horman
results.brief_description:
When Sunday went to live with her grandmother she didn’t have any friends to play with. One day a stray dog walked down the lane behind her house. It was missing a tail and an ear. Nobody wanted it. Sunday made friends with the dog but it was taken away to the pound. Weeks passed. Dogs were adopted and other dogs were led away to a big blue door. Finally, Sunday found the dog at the pound and adopted him. When they got home, Sunday made him a special hat with two ears and a tail for him to wag. Creators: Pepper Horman, Maddie Jamieson Goddard, Fionnuala Keith, Jennifer Petroploulos, Lucy Hanna, Declan Warren, Piper McLeod, Amy Phillips, Elan Cotter, Georgia Dickie, Isabella Godfrey, Lucinda McSherry, Millie Barnes, Nick Warren, Ella O’Donoghue, Isobel Hyett, Michael Guzzardi, Lucy Phillips, Clare Olding and Jagger Skilbeck.

Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Years 5 and 6, Yarraville West Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.
